prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require the beam size 0.57" which well matched to the ATCA 17.7 GHz beam size and Chandra resolution. To determine spectrum index accurately, we need 4 spectrum windows, and each spectrum window has 2 GHz bandwidth. When synchrotron cooling is effective, the preidcted flux of knot WK7.8 is 3.8 mJy/beam at 104 GHz. For 5 sigma detection, 1 sigma noise level of 0.76 mJy/beam for 2 GHz bandwidth is required. Total on source time 2 min is enough to achieve this sensitivity. Since the core peak flux is 1.7 Jy from ALMA calibrator list, the required Dynamic Range is 2200. This DR can be achieved by self-calibration imaging by ourselves.
For "desired sensitivity per pointing" with aggregate bandwidth 7.5 GHz, we double the required 1 sigma noise level for 2 GHz bandwidth.

We require the beam size 0.57" which well matched to the ATCA 17.7 GHz beam size and Chandra resolution. To determine spectrum index accurately, we need 4 spectrum windows, and each spectrum window has 2 GHz bandwidth. When synchrotron cooling is effective, the preidcted flux of knot WK7.8 is 2.6 mJy/beam at 141 GHz. For 5 sigma detection, 1 sigma noise level of 0.51 mJy/beam for 2 GHz bandwidth is required. Total on source time 2 min is enough to achieve this sensitivity. Since the core peak flux is ~1.6 Jy from ALMA calibrator list, the required Dynamic Range is 3100. This DR can be achieved by self-calibration imaging by ourselves.
For "desired sensitivity per pointing" with aggregate bandwidth 7.5 GHz, we double the required 1 sigma noise level for 2 GHz bandwidth.

To determine spectrum index accurately, we need 4 spectrum windows, and each spectrum window has 2 GHz bandwidth. When synchrotron cooling is effective, the preidcted flux of knot WK7.8 is 2.1 mJy/beam at 162 GHz. For 5 sigma detection, 1 sigma noise level of 0.43 mJy/beam for 2 GHz bandwidth is required. Total on source time 2 min is enough to achieve this sensitivity. Since the core peak flux is ~1.6 Jy from ALMA calibrator list, the required Dynamic Range is 3700. This DR can be achieved by self-calibration imaging by ourselves.
For "desired sensitivity per pointing" with aggregate bandwidth 7.5 GHz, we double the required 1 sigma noise level for 2 GHz bandwidth.

We require the beam size 0.57" which well matched to the ATCA 17.7 GHz beam size and Chandra resolution. To determine spectrum index accurately, we need 4 spectrum windows, and each spectrum window has 2 GHz bandwidth. When synchrotron cooling is effective, the preidcted flux of knot WK7.8 is 1.4 mJy/beam at 230 GHz. For 5 sigma detection, 1 sigma noise level of 0.27 mJy/beam for 2 GHz bandwidth is required. Total on source time 2 min is enough to achieve this sensitivity. Since the core peak flux is ~1.4 Jy from ALMA calibrator list, the required Dynamic Range is 5200. This DR can be achieved by self-calibration imaging by ourselves.
For "desired sensitivity per pointing" with aggregate bandwidth 7.5 GHz, we double the required 1 sigma noise level for 2 GHz bandwidth.

We require the beam size 0.57" which well matched to the ATCA 17.7 GHz beam size and Chandra resolution. To determine spectrum index accurately, we need 4 spectrum windows, and each spectrum window has 2 GHz bandwidth. When synchrotron cooling is effective, the preidcted flux of knot WK7.8 is 1.1 mJy/beam at 271 GHz. For 5 sigma detection, 1 sigma noise level of 0.22 mJy/beam for 2 GHz bandwidth is required. Total on source time 2 min is enough to achieve this sensitivity. Since the core peak flux is ~1.3 Jy from ALMA calibrator list, the required Dynamic Range is 5900. This DR can be achieved by self-calibration imaging by ourselves.
For "desired sensitivity per pointing" with aggregate bandwidth 7.5 GHz, we double the required 1 sigma noise level for 2 GHz bandwidth.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a continuum observation of the bright quasar jet PKS0637-752 at 4 spws for Band 3 and 8 spws for Band 4, and 6. We measure the flux of three bright Western Knots (WK7.8, 8.9, and 9.7) with their scale extending up to Mega pc scale. By combining this tomography mapping of the large jet by ALMA and co-spatial X-ray profile along the jet obtained by Chandra, we consistently determine the bulk Lorentz factor of each region and explore the jet deceleration process for the first time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00559.S, Tomography mapping the quasar jet PKS0637-752

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
